title: The 3 A's of awesome - Neil Pasricha

multiple-choice.question: What motivated the speaker to start his blog, "1000 Awesome Things"?

options.label: A
options.text: He wanted to become a famous blogger.

options.label: B
options.text: He wanted to focus on the positive aspects of life during a difficult time.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to make money from advertising.

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to share his expertise on a particular topic.

multiple-choice.question: What are the "Three A's of Awesome" according to the speaker?
What does the speaker mean by "attitude" in the context of the "Three A's of Awesome"?

options.label: A
options.text: Having a positive outlook on life, even in difficult times.

options.label: B
options.text: Being aggressive and competitive in all aspects of life.

options.label: C
options.text: Being passive and accepting of one's circumstances.

options.label: D
options.text: Being neutral and unemotional in all situations.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker illustrate the concept of "awareness"?

options.label: A
options.text: By describing a person who is an expert in a particular field.

options.label: B
options.text: By describing a three-year-old child who is experiencing the world for the first time.

options.label: C
options.text: By describing a person who is oblivious to their surroundings.

options.label: D
options.text: By describing a person who is distracted by technology.

multiple-choice.question: What is the story of Rosie Greer, and how does it relate to the concept of "authenticity"?

options.label: A
options.text: Rosie Greer was a football player who loved needlepoint, illustrating the importance of being true to oneself.

options.label: B
options.text: Rosie Greer was a football player who hated needlepoint, illustrating the importance of trying new things.

options.label: C
options.text: Rosie Greer was a needlepoint expert who loved football, illustrating the importance of having multiple interests.

options.label: D
options.text: Rosie Greer was a football player who had no hobbies, illustrating the importance of focusing on one's career.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about the fleeting nature of life?

options.label: A
options.text: That we should focus on accumulating wealth and material possessions.

options.label: B
options.text: That we should prioritize our careers above all else.

options.label: C
options.text: That we should appreciate the present moment and make the most of the time we have.

options.label: D
options.text: That we should be pessimistic about the future and expect the worst.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker's father illustrate the concept of appreciation for the small things in life?

options.label: A
options.text: By complaining about the food at a welcoming lunch for new immigrants.

options.label: B
options.text: By marveling at the variety of foods available at a grocery store.

options.label: C
options.text: By being disappointed by the lack of options at a restaurant.

options.label: D
options.text: By being unimpressed by the sights and sounds of a new city.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice for living a life that is "truly awesome"?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on achieving success and fame.

options.label: B
options.text: To prioritize one's career above all else.

options.label: C
options.text: To live with a great attitude, awareness, and authenticity.

options.label: D
options.text: To be pessimistic about the future and expect the worst.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker's personal story relate to the concept of resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: He gave up on his blog and his marriage after facing setbacks.

options.label: B
options.text: He continued to pursue his passions and interests despite facing challenges.

options.label: C
options.text: He became pessimistic about the future after experiencing difficulties.

options.label: D
options.text: He focused solely on his career after facing setbacks in his personal life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall tone of the speaker's message?

title: On reading the Koran - Lesley Hazleton

multiple-choice.question: What is the Quran's idea of paradise often misunderstood as?

options.label: B
options.text: A land of milk and honey

multiple-choice.question: According to the Quran, what is paradise actually described as?
Why does the speaker think people struggle to read the Quran?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is written in an ancient language

options.label: C
options.text: Because we imagine it can be read like a regular book

multiple-choice.question: What approach did the speaker take to reading the Quran?

options.label: A
options.text: They read it quickly, trying to finish it in one sitting

options.label: B
options.text: They read four translations side by side, along with the original Arabic

options.label: C
options.text: They skipped to the back to read the shorter chapters first

options.label: D
options.text: They only read the most well-known verses

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's background in relation to the Quran?

options.label: B
options.text: They are an agnostic Jew who has written about Islamic history

options.label: D
options.text: They are an atheist with no prior knowledge of the Quran

multiple-choice.question: What does the Quran declare it comes to do?

options.label: A
options.text: To contradict the Torah and the Gospels

options.label: B
options.text: To renew the message of the Torah and the Gospels

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the Arabic language of the Quran?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a simple, straightforward language

options.label: B
options.text: It has an incantatory, almost hypnotic quality

options.label: C
options.text: It is a language that can only be understood by Muslims

options.label: D
options.text: It is a language that is no longer spoken today

multiple-choice.question: What is the Quran's attitude towards the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: It emphasizes human dominance over nature

options.label: C
options.text: It shows a degree of environmental awareness and stewardship

options.label: D
options.text: It advocates for the destruction of the natural world

multiple-choice.question: What is the context of the infamous verse about killing unbelievers?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a general command to kill all non-Muslims

options.label: B
options.text: It is a specific permission to fight in the context of the conquest of Mecca

options.label: C
options.text: It is a verse that only applies to Muslims who have committed a crime

options.label: D
options.text: It is a verse that has been removed from modern translations of the Quran

multiple-choice.question: What is the Quran's description of the nature of paradise?

options.label: A
options.text: A place of virginity and abstinence

options.label: B
options.text: A place of fecundity and plenty

options.label: C
options.text: A place of eternal suffering and punishment

options.label: D
options.text: A place of nothingness and void

title: The Eisenhower matrix: understanding task management

multiple-choice.question: Who developed the Eisenhower matrix to support task prioritization by urgency and importance?

options.label: A
options.text: Former US President Franklin D. Roosevelt

options.label: C
options.text: Former US President Harry S. Truman

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of using the Eisenhower matrix in time management?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce stress and increase productivity

options.label: B
options.text: To prioritize tasks by importance but not urgency

options.label: C
options.text: To delegate all tasks to others

multiple-choice.question: Which quadrant in the Eisenhower matrix is referred to as the "Do First" sector?
What type of tasks should be listed in the "Schedule" sector of the Eisenhower matrix?

options.label: C
options.text: Tasks that can be delegated to others

multiple-choice.question: How can you effectively manage tasks in the "Do First" sector?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a timer to help you concentrate

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a task that could be delegated to others according to the Eisenhower matrix?

options.label: A
options.text: Reviewing an important document for your manager

options.label: B
options.text: Returning to the gym after a long break

options.label: C
options.text: Responding to an urgent favor request from someone

multiple-choice.question: What should you do with tasks that fall into the fourth quadrant of the Eisenhower matrix?
According to Dwight Eisenhower, what is the relationship between importance and urgency in tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: What's important is always urgent, and what's urgent is always important

options.label: B
options.text: What's important is seldom urgent, and what's urgent is seldom important

options.label: C
options.text: What's important is never urgent, and what's urgent is never important

options.label: D
options.text: What's important is sometimes urgent, and what's urgent is sometimes important

multiple-choice.question: How can you apply the Eisenhower matrix to your daily life to increase productivity?

options.label: A
options.text: By prioritizing tasks based on importance and urgency, and focusing on the most critical ones first

options.label: B
options.text: By delegating all tasks to others

options.label: C
options.text: By scheduling all tasks for later

multiple-choice.question: What is a common bad habit that can be eliminated by using the Eisenhower matrix?

options.label: A
options.text: Surfing the internet without a reason

options.label: B
options.text: Returning to the gym after a long break

options.label: C
options.text: Responding to urgent favor requests from others

options.label: D
options.text: Reviewing important documents for your manager

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Bewilder - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What is the root of the word "bewilder"?
What was the initial meaning of the Old English word "deor"?

options.label: D
options.text: A ruminant of the family Cervidae

multiple-choice.question: What is the meaning of the prefix "be" in the word "bewilder"?
How did the word "wilder" originate?
What was the original meaning of the word "wilderness"?

options.label: C
options.text: A tract of uncultivated land, primarily inhabited by undomesticated beasts

options.label: D
options.text: A ruminant of the family Cervidae

multiple-choice.question: What is the current definition of the word "bewilder"?

options.label: C
options.text: To be lost in the wild

multiple-choice.question: How did the word "bewilder" evolve over time?

options.label: A
options.text: From the Old English word "wilde" to the modern word "deer"

options.label: B
options.text: From the word "wilderness" to the word "wilder" and then to "bewilder"

options.label: C
options.text: From the prefix "be" to the word "wilderness"

options.label: D
options.text: From the Early Indo-European root "breathe" to the Old English word "deor"

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the words "wild" and "deor"?

options.label: C
options.text: They were often linked together in Old English

multiple-choice.question: What is the meaning of the word "wilder" in the context of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To lead someone astray or lure them into the woods

options.label: C
options.text: To be lost in the wild

multiple-choice.question: In what century was the prefix "be" compounded with "wilder" to form the word "bewilder"?

title: The walk from "no" to "yes" - William Ury

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the "Third Side" concept presented by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The Third Side refers to a neutral third party that mediates conflicts.

options.label: B
options.text: The Third Side refers to the community that surrounds a conflict and can play a constructive role in resolving it.

options.label: C
options.text: The Third Side refers to the opposing party in a conflict.

options.label: D
options.text: The Third Side refers to the government or authority that imposes a resolution on a conflict.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the secret to peace?

options.label: A
options.text: The secret to peace is the use of force to impose a resolution.

options.label: B
options.text: The secret to peace is the involvement of a neutral third party.

options.label: C
options.text: The secret to peace is us, the surrounding community that can play a constructive role.

options.label: D
options.text: The secret to peace is the absence of conflict altogether.

multiple-choice.question: What is the story of the 17 camels and the wise old woman meant to illustrate?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of compromise in conflict resolution.

options.label: B
options.text: The need for a neutral third party in conflict resolution.

options.label: C
options.text: The value of creative thinking in finding solutions to seemingly intractable problems.

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of respecting tradition and authority in conflict resolution.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Abraham Path, and what is its purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: The Abraham Path is a physical path that retraces the steps of Abraham, and its purpose is to promote tourism in the Middle East.

options.label: B
options.text: The Abraham Path is a metaphorical path that represents the journey towards peace and reconciliation, and its purpose is to promote understanding and respect among different cultures and faiths.

options.label: C
options.text: The Abraham Path is a historical route that marks the migration of Abraham and his family, and its purpose is to educate people about the history of the region.

options.label: D
options.text: The Abraham Path is a spiritual journey that aims to promote personal growth and self-discovery, and its purpose is to help individuals find inner peace.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the opposite of terrorism?

options.label: B
options.text: Taking an innocent stranger and treating them as a friend, welcoming them into your home, and creating understanding and respect.

options.label: C
options.text: Ignoring the problem and hoping it goes away.

options.label: D
options.text: Using force to impose a resolution.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the acorn that the speaker shows to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: The acorn represents the small beginnings of a big idea, the Abraham Path, which has the potential to grow and make a significant impact.

options.label: B
options.text: The acorn represents the speaker's love of nature and the outdoors.

options.label: C
options.text: The acorn represents the fragility of peace and the need for constant nurturing and care.

options.label: D
options.text: The acorn represents the strength and resilience of the human spirit.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the role of the Third Side in conflict resolution?

options.label: A
options.text: The Third Side imposes a resolution on the conflict.

options.label: B
options.text: The Third Side mediates between the opposing parties.

options.label: C
options.text: The Third Side reminds the parties of what's really at stake and helps them to see the bigger picture.

options.label: D
options.text: The Third Side takes sides and supports one party over the other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's vision for the Middle East, and how does the Abraham Path fit into it?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker's vision is for a Middle East that is divided and fragmented, with each country and culture separate and distinct, and the Abraham Path is a way to reinforce those divisions.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker's vision is for a Middle East that is united and at peace, with the Abraham Path serving as a symbol of that unity and a means of promoting understanding and respect among different cultures and faiths.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker's vision is for a Middle East that is dominated by one particular country or culture, with the Abraham Path serving as a means of asserting that dominance.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker's vision is for a Middle East that is secular and non-religious, with the Abraham Path serving as a way to promote secular values and downplay the role of faith.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the most important thing that individuals can do to contribute to peace and reconciliation?

options.label: A
options.text: The most important thing is to take a stand and assert one's own position and interests.

options.label: B
options.text: The most important thing is to listen to others and try to understand their perspectives and needs.

options.label: C
options.text: The most important thing is to seek common ground and compromise.

options.label: D
options.text: The most important thing is to use force and coercion to impose one's will on others.

multiple-choice.question: What is the African proverb that the speaker quotes, and what does it mean in the context of the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: The proverb is "When spider webs unite, they can halt even the lion," and it means that even the smallest and seemingly insignificant actions can collectively make a significant impact and bring about change.

options.label: B
options.text: The proverb is "A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush," and it means that it's better to appreciate what you have than to take risks and strive for more.

options.label: C
options.text: The proverb is "The squeaky wheel gets the grease," and it means that those who complain and make the most noise are the ones who get attention and action.

options.label: D
options.text: The proverb is "Might makes right," and it means that the strongest and most powerful are the ones who will ultimately prevail.

options.label: B
options.text: A couple of hours to a couple of weeks

options.label: B

title: Labor Day: Is it really a necessary holiday?

multiple-choice.question: In what century did the Industrial Revolution modernize the United States and Canada?
What was the main reason for US labor groups to start unionizing?

options.label: B
options.text: To protect themselves from exploitation in the workplace

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a new intercontinental ballistic missile

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

title: RNAi: Slicing, dicing and serving your cells - Alex Dainis

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of RNA in the cell?

options.label: A
options.text: To act as a messenger between DNA and the ribosome

options.label: D
options.text: To direct amino acids to their targets

multiple-choice.question: What is RNA interference (RNAi), and what is its purpose in the cell?

options.label: A
options.text: RNAi is a process that helps to translate messenger RNA into protein

options.label: B
options.text: RNAi is a process that helps to destroy RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus

options.label: C
options.text: RNAi is a process that helps to synthesize DNA

options.label: D
options.text: RNAi is a process that helps to regulate gene expression by destroying specific RNA molecules

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the protein dicer in the RNAi process?

options.label: B
options.text: To chop double-stranded RNA molecules into short snippets

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the RNA Silencing Complex (RISC) in the RNAi process?

options.label: B
options.text: To chop double-stranded RNA molecules into short snippets

options.label: C
options.text: To target matching mRNA molecules and slice them

options.label: D
options.text: To destroy RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus

multiple-choice.question: How was the RNAi process first discovered?

options.label: A
options.text: Through experiments with C. elegans worms

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential therapeutic application of RNAi?

options.label: C
options.text: To target and destroy cancer-causing genes

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate gene expression in plants

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the mRNA molecule once it is targeted by RISC?

options.label: B
options.text: It is sliced into smaller pieces

options.label: C
options.text: It is destroyed by the cell

options.label: D
options.text: It is modified to produce a different protein

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the slicer protein in the RISC complex?

options.label: A
options.text: To chop double-stranded RNA molecules into short snippets

multiple-choice.question: How can researchers use RNAi to their advantage in understanding gene function?

options.label: A
options.text: By introducing an RNAi construct to knock out a specific gene

options.label: B
options.text: By using RNAi to synthesize proteins directly

options.label: C
options.text: By using RNAi to create DNA

options.label: D
options.text: By using RNAi to regulate gene expression in plants

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome of using RNAi to target cancer-causing genes?

options.label: A
options.text: The cell will produce more cancer-causing proteins

options.label: B
options.text: The cell will produce fewer cancer-causing proteins

options.label: C
options.text: The cell will become resistant to cancer

title: 300 years of fossil fuels in 300 seconds

multiple-choice.question: When was the earth formed?

title: The science of macaroni salad: What's in a mixture? - Josh Kurz

multiple-choice.question: What is a mixture in physical science?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of two or more things that doesn't change their chemical identity

options.label: C
options.text: A single substance that cannot be broken down further

options.label: D
options.text: A process of breaking chemical bonds

options.label: C
options.text: To change the chemical properties of particles

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the size of particles

options.label: D
options.text: Physical unmixing does not involve changing the chemical properties of particles, while chemical unmixing does
